title: 114_hr6235
content: SECTION 1. LAND TRANSFER. The Secretary of the Army will transfer land to the Secretary of the Interior for the benefit of the Tribe and to the State of North Dakota. This includes transferring property within the Reservation boundaries in North Dakota to be held in trust for the Tribe. The term "Reservation" refers to the Standing Rock Indian Reservation, and the term "Tribe" refers to the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe of North and South Dakota. The property acquired for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project will be under the administrative control of the Corps of Engineers. The Secretary of the Army will transfer land to the Secretary of the Interior for the benefit of the Tribe and to the State of North Dakota. The Secretary of the Army will transfer all right, title, and interest of the United States in covered property in North Dakota to the State of North Dakota. Covered property includes land acquired for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project in certain counties, above the exclusive flood pool, and under the Corps of Engineers' control. The transfer of land from the Army Corps of Engineers to the State of North Dakota for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project must not interfere with authorized purposes or laws. The Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Program is defined as authorized by the Flood Control Act of 1944. The United States is not liable for any damage to the transferred land due to the dam's operation. The Secretary of the Army retains rights to inundate or cause erosion to transferred lands for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Army also retains any necessary property interests for authorized purposes. The Secretary of the Army may impose additional terms for land transfer to ensure the Oahe Dam's operation. Existing rights and interests in the land will be preserved. The Army will create a map identifying land needed for project purposes over a 20-year period. The Standing Rock Sioux Tribe and the State of North Dakota are responsible for all costs associated with the transfer of land for project purposes. The map identifying necessary land will be on file with the Secretary of the Army.
